p: Biosurfactants can emulsify hydrocarbons enhancing their water solubility, decreasing surface tension and increasing the displacement of oil substances from soil particles [ 3, 6, 8, 54]. Results described in the literature show that the biosurfactants produced by strains of P. aeruginosa removed 49–54% of crude oil adsorbed in sand [ 71], whereas Silva et al. [ 60] demonstrated high removal rates (above 85%) of diesel oil from sand samples, but less than 20% when petroleum was tested. In this study, the crude biosurfactant produced by S. marcescens UCP 1549 was able to remove 94% of motor oil contained in sand, while the distilled water (control) removed only 63% (Fig. 8) (Additional file 1: Table S2). Similarly, Nalini and Parthasarathi [ 55] showed the recovery of 92% of used engine oil adsorbed in sand by biosurfactant from S. rubidae.
